text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-width horizontal miniature at top of the folio, framed by a thin border and a Gothic micro-architectural canopy, with two narrow columns of text running directly beneath the image. The illustration dominates the page, creating a clear visual hierarchy in which the image introduces the subject before the reader proceeds to the text.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with clear justification, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for halos and the canopy, symbolizing divine authority. Ultramarine blue used for Christ’s robe to emphasize heavenly status, vermilion for the bishop-elect’s undergarments. Leaf green on secondary drapery. White highlights model fabric folds. Alternating red and blue in border tracery. Original pigments appear well-preserved with minimal darkening of lead white.

features: Two kneeling bishops flanking the central axis
Vertical emphasis in the central canopy structure
Symmetrical balance between left and right registers
Diagonal gesture line from Christ’s hand to the bishop-elect’s head

decorative_elements: Gothic micro-architectural canopy with pinnacles and quatrefoil tracery
Thin rectangular frame with inked border lines
Stylized foliate motifs in canopy spandrels

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen work with varying line weight, bold outlines for figures and canopy, finer internal detailing for drapery and facial features
drawing_technique.shading_method: Parallel hatching in drapery folds, cross-hatching in shadowed areas, white lead highlighting to suggest volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without geometric perspective, overlapping figures to indicate depth, larger central figure of Christ compared to the attended bishops

content_theme.scene_description: A single full-scene miniature depicts the ordination of a bishop. At center, Christ stands within a Gothic canopy, his right hand raised in blessing and his left placing a jewelled crown or mitre onto the bowed head of the kneeling bishop-elect. The bishop-elect clasps a crozier in his left hand and bows deeply, his trimmed tonsure visible. To Christ’s right, Saint Peter emerges from a cloud holding a large key, gesturing toward the ceremony. On the lower register, two fully vested bishops kneel in mirrored poses at either side of the canopy; each holds a crozier and wears a mitre, acting as witnesses. All figures wear long flowing robes with layered drapery—Christ’s robe marked by cascading folds and white highlights, the bishops’ garments lined with contrasting pigments. The spatial organization is strictly hierarchical: Christ and the bishop-elect occupy the central plane, elevated on a narrow platform. Overlapping garments and the implied step of the platform indicate depth. Costumes display status: gold-embellished hems, embroidered edging on stoles, and ornate croziers. The background is left plain to focus attention on the ritual act.

religious: Christ blessing and crowning the bishop-elect
Saint Peter with key emerging from cloud

architectural: Gothic micro-architectural canopy with pointed arches, pinnacles, quatrefoil tracery

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth surface with fine hair-follicle pattern visible under magnification. Folio is part of a quaternion gathering, margins ruled in plummet and ink.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments and gold leaf are well-preserved with minimal flaking. Slight cockling at corners. Evidence of modern stabilization along lower margin.
notable_physical_characteristics: Visible underdrawing in brown ink under the figures
Regular ruling pattern for text and image baseline
Raised gesso under gold leaf in halos and canopy details
Punchwork patterns in gold to articulate halos

functional_analysis.primary_function: Liturgical use – ordination manual or pontifical used during episcopal consecration ceremonies
secondary_functions: Visual aid for the ordination rite
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Cathedral clergy, especially the consecrating bishops and archbishop officiating the ordination

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illumination likely originated in a high-status episcopal workshop in the late 13th century, perhaps in northern France or England, reflecting the elaborate pontificals produced for cathedral use. The central placement of Christ and the incorporation of Saint Peter underscore a theological emphasis on apostolic authority, affirming the bishop-elect’s succession to the apostolic see. The micro-architectural canopy with its delicate tracery situates the scene within the vernacular Gothic style then popular in urban scriptoria. Stylistically, the crisp line work, tiered hatching, and restrained yet luminous palette demonstrate a mature workshop practice, possibly linked to the circle of the Parisian atelier that illuminated the Pontifical of Paris. The depiction balances liturgical precision—accurate vestments, correct implement of the crozier, and ceremonial gestures—with an iconographic program that celebrates the divine sanction of ecclesiastical office. Comparisons with contemporaneous pontificals, such as the Pontifical of St. Hugh of Grenoble, reveal shared conventions in figure type and canopy design, while the punched-gesso halos and pointed canopy finials suggest a localized adaptation of the Île-de-France idiom. This image thus exemplifies the fusion of ritual function, doctrinal messaging, and Gothic artistic innovation in high medieval manuscript culture.
